tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for Thursday October 1 records: "Beginning of lessons: Mrs. Deutsch opens the season. [...]"

Schenker's diary for Saturday October 3 records: "Mrs. Pairamall cancels, again referring to reasons already once put forward, but in fact at least to some extent to soften the impact of the feeling of shame."

tei:div.tei:head: Elias:
tei:div.tei:ab: Erster Choral der Mattäus-Passion in verschieden Fassungen mit Stimmführungserläuterungen. Brahms, Intermezzo op. 119, 2.A letter from Elias (diary, September 16) confirmed that the number of lessons she would take remained the same as that in 1913/14, in which season she received three lessons per week, Monday, Wednesday, Saturday. Only five lessons are recorded in the 1914/15 lessonbook, and they occur on a Wednesday (Oct 21), two Thursdays (Oct 8, Feb 6), and a Saturday (Mar 20), with one indeterminate, so it is impossible to build a complete picture of her lesson schedule.

tei:div.tei:head: Elias:
tei:div.tei:ab: First chorale from the St. Matthew Passion in different versions with elucidations of voice-leading. Brahms Intermezzo Op. 119, No. 2.

tei:div.tei:head: Zuckerkandl:
tei:div.tei:ab: Verborgene Zusammenhänge in Brahms’ Trio, op. 8; Klavierquintett; Beethovens op. 111; über Regel u. Ausnahme.Zuckerkandl had attended his first lesson on October 1 as per Schenker's diary: "In the afternoon a new pupil appears, who is indeed quick-witted but unfortunately suffers from nervous tension."

tei:div.tei:head: Zuckerkandl:
tei:div.tei:ab: Hidden connections in Brahms's Trio, Op. 8; Piano Quintet; Beethoven Op. 111; on rules and exceptions.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: wird schon jetzt zu dreifacher Art der Ausfertigung der Generalbaßaufgaben angeleitet, weil er zu sehr die Norm mißachtet.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Is introduced at this early stage to the threefold method of copying thoroughbass exercises, because he too frequently disregards the norm.

tei:div.tei:head: Breisach:
tei:div.tei:ab: Wegen Sehnenzerrung: V. Sinfonie, 1. Satz eingeschoben; gründlichstes Studium mit Literaturbelegen, Weingartner u.s.f. Br. macht Notizen!From the days recorded here and in Schenker's diary, Breisach's lessons were on Mondays and Fridays.

tei:div.tei:head: Breisach:
tei:div.tei:ab: On account of a strained tendon: Fifth Symphony first movement interjected; the most rigorous study using secondary-literature evidence, Weingartner and so forth Breisach makes notes!

tei:div.tei:head: Kahn:
tei:div.tei:ab: Etuden v. Chopin (II. Heft.) Asd, Fd, Am.

tei:div.tei:head: Kahn:
tei:div.tei:ab: Chopin Etudes (Book II) in A major, F major, A minor.

tei:div.tei:head: Hupka:
tei:div.tei:ab: Rhapsodie, neu.

tei:div.tei:head: Hupka:
tei:div.tei:ab: Rhapsody, new.

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for Monday October 12 records: "Mrs. Colbert, in opposition to the indications in her first letter of cancellation, not only comes to her lesson at exactly the right time but also seeks to take advantage of me! It also turns out finally, to my greatest surprise, that she had to go to the rehearsal of Messiah; in short it turns out that everything she wrote was simply a lie."

Schenker's diary for Friday October 16 records: "Breisach appears again for his lesson. The explanation of the notorious passage in the development section [of the Fifth Symphony], where Beethoven prepares to regain the recapitulation, specifically from the emergence and effect of the triplet figure, moved him so much that, innocently and trustingly in equal measure, he puts the question as to why I alone could provide an answer, whether it was due to [my] work or talent, and so on. In my reply I stressed above all the phenomenon, which Breisach could also find confirmed by Weingartner, that every genius-endowed sign contains something ultimately concealed, which most people could only approach to a limited extent; and even those very people who appeared to come very close still always remained sufficiently far away. In this way, I wished to give some insight into the true depths of things about which it is merely the case that the talented person cannot approach it. But the boy seems not to have properly understood the reference to the matter; and he seemed more interested in the person than in the matter, and the question of his value and categorization."

tei:div.tei:head: Elias:
tei:div.tei:ab: Brahms, Intermezzo op. 119, No 3 neu.

tei:div.tei:head: Elias:
tei:div.tei:ab: Brahms Intermezzo Op. 119, No. 3 new.

tei:div.tei:head: Deutsch:
tei:div.tei:ab: Brahms, Sonate Dm, Analyse 1. Satz zuende; Betrachtung der Form des 2. S.

tei:div.tei:head: Deutsch:
tei:div.tei:ab: Brahms, Sonata in D minor, analysis of the first movement to the end; examination of the form of the second movement.

tei:ab.tei:note: Zuckerkandl was due for a lesson on this day but canceled on account of illness (diary). Schenker wrote inquiring as to his health on October 26 and phoned on October 28. He was still absent on Dec 28. Together, these suggest that he was scheduled for lessons on Mondays and Thursdays.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Für Adler, SeminarAt this time, Weisse was a member of Guido Adler's seminar at the Musikhistorisches Institut of the University of Vienna; in 1919 he obtained his PhD from the University for a dissertation on the "instrumental art waltz," under the direction of Adler.: Brahms-Haydn-Variationen.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: For Adler Seminar: Brahms, Haydn Variations.

tei:div.tei:head: Hupka:
tei:div.tei:ab: beginnt Generalbaß;i.e. C. P. E. Bach, Versuch über die wahre Art ..., Part II (Berlin: Winter, 1762), "Generalbass"; see Eng. transl. by W. J. Mitchell (1949), chapter 5, pp. 198‒311 "Thorough Bass." There is no record of Hupka continuing theory studies in 1914/15 or 1915/16. auch einiges aus der 1. Sinf. v. Beethoven.

tei:div.tei:head: Hupka:
tei:div.tei:ab: Begins thoroughbass; also several points in the Beethoven First Symphony.

tei:div.tei:head: Deutsch:
tei:div.tei:ab: Form der beiden letzten Sätze aus op. 108, nur flüchtig!

tei:div.tei:head: Deutsch:
tei:div.tei:ab: Form of the last two movements of Op. 108, only cursorily!

tei:div.tei:head: Colbert:
tei:div.tei:ab: Intermezzo op. 117, No 2; flüchtige Analyse.

tei:div.tei:head: Colbert:
tei:div.tei:ab: Intermezzo Op. 117, No. 2; cursory analysis.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Haydn-Var. zuende; sehr hübsche Analyse von ihm selbst. Ueber das Liszt’sche Esd-Konzert.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Haydn Variations to the end; very elegant analysis all on his own. On the Liszt E major Concerto.

tei:div.tei:head: Breisach:
tei:div.tei:ab: aus der Literatur zur V. Sinfonie: KretzschmarReference is to his Führer durch den Konzertsaal (Leipzig: Liebeskind, 1888–90), of which Schenker had the three-volume edition in his personal library at his death. u. Grove.Reference is to Sir George Grove's Beethoven and His Nine Symphonies (London: Novello, [1896]), of which Schenker had the German translation by Max Hehemann (London, 1906) in his personal library at his death.

tei:div.tei:head: Breisach:
tei:div.tei:ab: From the secondary literature of the Fifth Symphony: Kretzschmar and Grove.

tei:dateline.tei:note: This is the second lesson entry for Deutsch recorded on October 26 (the date sequence, underline=Deutsch, being 26, 26, 27, 27, 26, 27, 29): while Schenker could have given her two lessons in one day, it would have been logical for him to place the two adjacent in the lessonbook rather than separated by three other entries. It is thus conceivable that one or other date may be incorrect. However, Monday and Thursday are the days on which all other lessons this saison were given, and the 26th and 29th were Monday and Thursday, respectively.

tei:div.tei:head: Deutsch:
tei:div.tei:ab: für Kogan: Ballade Asd, Chopin; Etude Gesd, No 21."No. 21" counts the two sets of etudes, Op. 10 and Op. 25, as a single number sequence (12 + 9 = 21).

tei:div.tei:head: Deutsch:
tei:div.tei:ab: For Kogan: Chopin Ballade in A major, Etude in G major, No. 21.

tei:dateline.tei:note: This is the second lesson entry for Weisse recorded on October 27, the date sequence, underline=Weisse, being 27, 27, 26, 27, 29, Nov 2, 3); while Schenker could have given him two lessons in one day, it would have been logical for him to place the two adjacent in the lessonbook rather than separated by two other entries. It is thus conceivable that one or other date may be incorrect. Since Weisse's lessons usually took place on Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday, it is likely that this entry should have been Oct 28 or 30, which were Wednesday and Friday, respectively.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Brahms Sinfonie Cm: einiges aus dem 1. Satz.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Brahms Symphony in C minor: some points from the first movement.

tei:div.tei:head: Deutsch:
tei:div.tei:ab: für Kogan: Chopin Scherzo Cismoll.

tei:div.tei:head: Deutsch:
tei:div.tei:ab: For Kogan: Chopin Scherzo in C minor.

tei:div.tei:head: Zuckerkandl:
tei:div.tei:ab: V. Sinfonie v. Beeth., 1. Satz u. Scherzo.

tei:div.tei:head: Zuckerkandl:
tei:div.tei:ab: Beethoven, Fifth Symphony, first movement and scherzo.

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for Monday November 2 records: "Mrs. Colbert turns up too late for her lesson, and thus receives a rebuke; and since she is indignant about this, she receives a rebuke that is all the stronger."

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Erste Choral-Studie: Seb. Bach’s 1. Choras Chorus The first chorus incorporates the chorale O Lamm Gottes unschuldig, sung by a ripieno soprano line. aus der Matthäus-Passion.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: First chorale study: J. S. Bach, first choras chorus of the St. Matthew Passion.

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary records on Tuesday November 3: "Brünauer appears for his first lesson, admits to being guilty of a discourtesy and intimates by the expression 'that it is indeed his fault' that he has ring-fenced the lesson fee for October for me. He shows himself to be bearable in other ways, too, so that I can now, without hesitation, give him the pleasure of my analysis of the first movement of the Fifth Symphony."

Schenker's diary for Friday November 13 records: "Brünauer reports that he has paid the lesson fee for October. – First introduction to thoroughbass." This probably means embarking on C. P. E. Bach, Versuch über die wahre Art ..., Part II (Berlin: Winter, 1762), "Generalbass"; see Eng. transl. by W. J. Mitchell (1949), chapter 5, pp. 198‒311 "Thorough Bass."

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Eroika, 1. S., die schwierigsten Stellen.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Eroica, first movement, the most difficult passages.

tei:div.tei:head: Breisach:
tei:div.tei:ab: Eroika, 1. Satz.

tei:div.tei:head: Breisach:
tei:div.tei:ab: Eroica, first movement.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Eroika.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Eroica.

tei:div.tei:head: Breisach:
tei:div.tei:ab: Eroika.

tei:div.tei:head: Breisach:
tei:div.tei:ab: Eroica.

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for November 4 records: "Mrs. Pairamall for her first lesson, at which I now go over that which had remained unsaid as a result of my stubborn refusal to receive her. After more than two hours the status quo was reached, palliated only by cheap phrases; that is, Mrs. P. again imagines that I think her as respectable as I had previously, in the belief of which I must therefore leave her – only because she would only be cured of it if I were permitted to say openly to her face that she is the opposite of that. But so long as this is impossible – and who would regard it as being at all possible – she will retain the vanity to believe that she could be seen as she is. However, these are all trivialities; the main thing remains the fulfillment of obligation on my part, and on hers."

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Angi Elias: lesson: end of November

tei:div.tei:head: Elias:
tei:div.tei:ab: Brahms, Klavier-Quintett, Fm.This imprecise dating is likely to refer to either November 25 or 27 (or even a combination of the two).

tei:div.tei:head: Elias:
tei:div.tei:ab: Brahms Piano Quintet in F minor.

tei:div.tei:head: Kahn:
tei:div.tei:ab: Chopin Nocturne Gd, Desd, Esd.

tei:div.tei:head: Kahn:
tei:div.tei:ab: Chopin Nocturnes in G major, D major, E major.

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for Monday December 28 records: "Mrs. Colbert appears for her lesson, while Mr. Zuckerkandl was still absent. So this lady who in her first letter had pompously announced to me a gift of 40 Kronen per month until February, with a gesture to which only the greediest sentiment can give rise, this very lady, I say, not only came to all of her lessons but also took upon herself the duties of teaching and, for instance, to cut Miss Kahn from her pupils!"

Schenker's diary for Tuesday December 29: "Shortly before Brünauer's lesson, Mrs. Pairamall appears, [...] Brünauer tells me that he is first going to accompany his family to Tutzing, but may also travel to Italy."

Schenker's diary for Tuesday December 29 records: "Weisse reads out a considerable portion of his work on the waltzes; since it is solidly based and eloquently written, I offer to recommend it immediately to Hertzka." This was the precursor to his dissertation on the "instrumental art waltz," written under the direction of Guido Adler, with which Weisse gained his PhD from the University of Vienna in 1919.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: beschließt die AppassionataThere is no record in the lessonbooks of Weisse having studied the "Appassionata" earlier this fall or at the end of 1913/14.; neu Chopin: Etude Cism; Nocturne Fisdur.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Finishes the Appassionata; new Chopin: Etude in C minor, Nocturne in F major.

tei:div.tei:head: Hupka:
tei:div.tei:ab: Chopin, Etude Edur

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for Saturday January 2 records: "Miss Kahn speaks of the immense greed of Brünauer’s mother." — Saturday is Kahn's regular lesson day.

Schenker's diary for Monday January 4 records: "Mrs. Deutsch appears for her first lesson since the holidays ...". In a long diatribe, Schenker comments that she: "stole a quarter of an hour of mine before her lesson at 11 o'clock and half an hour after it ...".

Schenker's diary for Wednesday January 13 records: "Weisse asks about Brahms's Variations on a Theme of Schumann, Op. 23, for the purposes of a Adler's seminar." Whether this took place in a lesson is uncertain. The variations feature in his lesson on January 19.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Schubert-Walzer vom ersten bis letzten

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Schubert waltzes from first to last.

tei:div.tei:head: Kahn:
tei:div.tei:ab: Chopin, Nocturne Fisd.This entry appears in the lessonbook before that of January 15 (Weisse).

tei:div.tei:head: Kahn:
tei:div.tei:ab: Chopin Nocturne in F major.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: für seminaristische Zweckei.e. the seminar, led by Guido Adler, at the Musikhistorisches Institut of the University of Vienna, from which Weisse obtained a PhD in 1919. Brahms, Variationen 4-händig, op. 23.The work was previously mentioned in Schenker's diary for January 13.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: For seminar purposes Brahms, Variations, Op. 23, four hands.

tei:div.tei:head: Brünauer:Brünauer had been away on military service, and Schenker's diary for January 12 reports: "Dr. Brünauer announces his return."
tei:div.tei:ab: Chopin, Etude Cism.

tei:div.tei:head: Brünauer:
tei:div.tei:ab: Chopin Etude in C minor.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Präludes von Chopin: Gd, Fm, Am.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Chopin, Preludes in G major, F minor, A minor.

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for Friday February 5 records: "Hans brings a new song, which he dedicates to Lie-Liechen; it is short, but splendid and effective, in many respects also original, with the transitions also competently written." ‒ Friday was a regular lesson day for Weisse.

tei:div.tei:head: Elias:
tei:div.tei:ab: Chopin, Etude Cism neu.

tei:div.tei:head: Elias:
tei:div.tei:ab: Chopin, Etude in C minor new.

tei:div.tei:head: Pairamall:
tei:div.tei:ab: Generalbaß.i.e. C. P. E. Bach, Versuch über die wahre Art ..., Part II (Berlin: Winter, 1762), Generalbass; see Eng. transl. by W. J. Mitchell (1949), chapter 5, pp. 198‒311 Thorough Bass. This the start of Pairamall's study of this subject as recorded in lessonbooks 1914/15 and 1915/16, finishing in January/February 1916.

tei:div.tei:head: Pairamall:
tei:div.tei:ab: thoroughbass.

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for Tuesday February 9 records: "Weisse’s relationship to Prof. Adler is increasingly coming to a head, as it could have not been expected to do otherwise; and the former is allowing it to come to a breach without further ado. To Adler’s invitation to begin [the seminar] on Friday with a presentation of his paper, Weisse replied evasively, only to give the professor the opportunity of first taking in the poison intended for him in written form. The effect of the injection will then determine whether Weisse will, or will not, himself present his work to inadequate ears." Tuesday was a regular lesson day for Weisse.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Brahms op. 8. - beide Ausgaben als neue Studien.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Brahms Op. 8. – the two editions as new studies.

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for Wednesday February 24 records: "Weisse presents me with his completed study, 'The Artistic Waltz,' with a dedication!" This was the precursor to his dissertation on the "instrumental art waltz," written under the direction of Guido Adler, with which Weisse gained his PhD from the University of Vienna in 1919. — Wednesday was a regular lesson day for Weisse: he was to present the study to Adler's seminar on Friday 26, which would also have been a normal lesson day.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Liebeslieder-Walzer von Brahms.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Brahms Liebeslieder-Waltzes.

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for Friday February 26 records: "Breisach takes his leave, for the time being, and hints at an early return; at the same time he asks me for piano lessons, in particular preparation in chamber music." (He and Hupka had volunteered for military service on February 20.) Consequently, the diary for Tuesday March 2 records: "For the first time, Breisach’s lesson is not in the calendar; we use the extra time to move forward more quickly on the last part of the work. [...]

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: II. Sinfonie von Brahms; Violin-Konzert v. Brahms.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Brahms Second Symphony; Brahms Violin-Concerto.

tei:div.tei:head: Kahn:
tei:div.tei:ab: Deutsche Tänze von Schubert.

tei:div.tei:head: Kahn:
tei:div.tei:ab: Schubert Deutsche Tänze.

tei:div.tei:head: Elias:
tei:div.tei:ab: Chopin: Prälude No 1; synoptische Studien zum Quintett von Schumann u. Quintett Brahms.

tei:div.tei:head: Elias:
tei:div.tei:ab: Chopin Prelude No. 1; synoptic studies for the Schumann Quintet and Brahms Quintet.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: (Nachtrag) Beeth. Sonate Fisd; Chopin: Etude Ed.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: (supplementary lesson) Beethoven Sonata in F major; Chopin Etude in E major.

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for Friday March 5 records: "Brünauer fails the second recruitment test. In the evening at his lesson, he is very nervous but still plays the hero, just so as not to appear cowardly. I clarify his uneasy mood for him by laying the blame for this on our state, and on the party system and on journalism, so that he, though by nature shy and without courage, can nevertheless feel free of guilt.
Schenker's diary for Monday March 8 records: "Zuckerkandl appears for his lesson but asks for it to be rescheduled, to which I immediately agree."

Schenker's diary for Thursday March 11 records: "Mrs. Deutsch asks me to hear and examine little Miss Kogan. Initially she sounded me out with regard to the remaining lesson time; but in the end she reflected on the matter and took care to impose a loss of time on me, to her benefit. ‒ Thursday was a regular lesson day for Deutsch.

Schenker's diary for Friday March 12 records: "Weisse reports that Adler praised his work extraordinarily, especially the analysis of the Brahms waltzes (!), even thanking him for his great effort and his evident industriousness. Thus brought into a state of embarrassment, Weisse for his part had to thank Adler for his musicological guidance, whereupon the latter said, with a patronizing smile, 'Yes, that’s something you are learning here with me.'
Most amusing, of course, was that Adler, when confronted by 'causality' Causalität and 'synthesis' Synthese, i.e. those terms that I myself use with my pupils and in my writings, wanted in all cases to replace them with the concept of 'style,' which he propagated in his own writings. Adler’s obsession is all the more grotesque in its effect as he still does not understand at all what Weisse – what I – mean by causality and synthesis. The end result is also this: that Adler himself apparently does not connect 'style' with anything precise, correct; for otherwise he would have to know whether he can use this concept at all where I speak about 'causality' and 'synthesis'." — Friday was a regular lesson day for Weisse.

tei:dateline.tei:note: Schenker's diary gives doubly conflicting information. The entry for Monday March 15 states: "A new pupil, Miss König, introduces herself, with her mother; and the arrangement is made in the same way that I have agreed with Hupka." The diary entry for Wednesday March 17 records: "Miss König for her first lesson," whereas the lessonbook entry not only contradicts that date but also indicates that study involved continuation from some previous occasion.

tei:div.tei:head: König:
tei:div.tei:ab: Fortsetz. der Sonate op. 109 v. Beeth; Chopin: Etude Cd.

tei:div.tei:head: König:
tei:div.tei:ab: Further study of Beethoven's Sonata Op. 109; Chopin Etude in C major.

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for Friday March 19 records: "Brünauer returns from Tutzing and appears in the evening for his lesson."

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Deutsche Tänze von Schubert. Beethoven: VIII. Sinfonie, letzter Satz.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Schubert Deutsche Tänze. Beethoven: Eighth Symphony, last movement.

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for Tuesday March 30 records: "Brünauer, battered by his nerves, emits a stream of the most severe statements about Germany – a reversal, which clearly shows that no arguments will be sufficient to protect Germany’s worth from slanderous statements." — Tuesday was a fairly regular lesson day for Breisach.

Schenker's diary for Tuesday March 30 records: "Weisse alerts me to a passage from Schopenhauer’s A Man’s Place in the Estimation of Others, which might merit being quoted in the introduction to my Erläuterungsausgabe, Op. 111. — Tuesday was a regular lesson day for Weisse.
Schenker's diary for Saturday April 3 records: "Mrs. Pairamall appears in the evening (Holy Saturday) for her lesson, but does not find me at home; letter to her explaining why."

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Schumann: Klavier-Quartett Esdur; Berlioz: Symphonie phantastique.

tei:div.tei:head: Weisse:
tei:div.tei:ab: Schumann Piano Quartet in E major; Berlioz Symphonie fantastique.

tei:ab.tei:note: Schenker's diary for Thursday April 8 records: "Mrs. Deutsch turns up unexpectedly for her lesson, as she says: because much work awaits her here. A real conjuror's sleight-of-hand performed by a rich woman [...]" A long diatribe by Schenker follows in which he rebukes her for "egoism" and questions her morals.

Schenker's diary for April 30 records: "For the first time, I mention to Weisse that I would be glad to move to Munich. He declares himself willing to go with me, to which particularly domestic conditions would impel him." Continues with stories of the Adler seminar. — Friday was a regular lesson day for Weisse.

Schenker's diary for Friday June 4 records: "Weisse comes for his lesson, rather self-consciously, for he would have gladly spared himself the monthly tuition fee. Indecisively, he throws down one excuse after another, for instance that he can no longer pull himself together, that he doesn’t know whether he’ll be able to come – then he again asks if he may come to his usual lesson, but qualifies the request with the suspicious words “all of a sudden.” … But I am steadfast in providing him with tuition in order to endow him with a kind of double benefit, by not only providing teaching material but also giving him a useful lesson in morality. – Weisse speaks again about Adler, and in fact about his politeness. Thereupon I make myself clearer, and offer examples which show that Adler has been playing a game of intrigue for years – admittedly only out of his incapacity – and to a certain extent with personal sharpness I demonstrate that it is only the incapacity of the person that lets off steam in impolite actions. – It is almost the case that I shall actually have to regard Weisse’s current behavior, too, as a first sign of incapacity." ‒ Friday was a regular lesson day for Weisse.

Schenker's diary for Saturday June 5 records: "Breisach does not turn up to his lesson, but without cancelling. I sense this to be a reply to my demand for the 20 Kronen that are still outstanding." — Previously the diary entry for April 19 records: "Breisach’s father gets in touch with me to discuss matters concerning his son; at the same time a postcard from the young Breisach arrives from Marburg, announcing his return, thus to a certain extent explaining the purpose of the father’s visit. — Mr. Breisach is requested to come on Wednesday April 21"; and the entry for April 21 records: "In the morning, young Breisach appears and announces the resumption of lessons; in the afternoon his father, overtaken by his son to some extent. To my surprise, he asks me for a third weekly lesson for his son."

sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Felix Hupka: lessons: mid-May to mid-June, 1916
Marianne Kahn: lessons: mid-May to mid-June, 1916
